Capronia coronata CBS 617.96 is a fungal species that belongs to the Ascomycota phylum. It is a member of the Herpotrichiellaceae family, which is known for its dark-colored, septate hyphae and the production of perithecia (flask-shaped fruiting bodies).

Capronia coronata is a saprobic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter. It has been isolated from various substrates, including wood and plant debris. The species is characterized by its unique perithecia, which are covered with long, dark, septate appendages, giving them a "crowned" appearance. These appendages are thought to aid in the dispersal of the fungal spores.

Microscopically, the asci (spore-bearing structures) of Capronia coronata are clavate (club-shaped) and contain eight ascospores. The ascospores are typically dark-colored, ellipsoid or fusiform in shape, and may exhibit septation (division into cells).

Capronia coronata is considered an important member of the fungal community in its natural habitats, contributing to the decomposition of organic matter and nutrient cycling within the ecosystem.
